questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his family due to a change in his mental status. They report that the patient seemed "confused" over the past two days. He had been previously diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment. On examination, the patient has fluctuating attention and is easily distracted. Which of the following best distinguishes his current presentation from his previous cognitive condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. Acute change and fluctuating course.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The key features distinguishing delirium from dementia are the acuteness of onset and the fluctuating course . Delirium is characterized by a sudden change in cognition over hours to days, whereas dementia is typically a chronic condition with a gradual onset. The fluctuating course of delirium means that symptoms can change in severity throughout the day, often worsening in the evening (termed " sundowning ").
  • • acuteness of onset
  • • fluctuating course
  • • sundowning
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A) Gradual onset of symptoms: This is characteristic of dementia, not delirium.
  • • Option A) Gradual onset of symptoms:
  • • Option B) Presence of visual hallucinations: While visual hallucinations can be present in both conditions, they are more commonly associated with certain types of dementia, such as Lewy-Body Dementia. However, they are not a distinguishing feature between dementia and delirium.
  • • Option B) Presence of visual hallucinations:
  • • Option C) Impairment in short-term memory: Memory impairment is a hallmark of many types of dementia, but it can also be seen in delirium.
  • • Option C) Impairment in short-term memory:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 230.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with a 6-month history of recurrent nightmares, flashbacks, and severe anxiety. She reports that these symptoms began after she was involved in a serious car accident where she witnessed several fatalities. She also avoids driving and experiences a heightened startle response. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is diagnosed when symptoms such as nightmares, flashbacks, avoidance behaviors, and hyperarousal persist for more than one month after exposure to a traumatic event. This patient's symptoms align with PTSD.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Acute Stress Disorder - Typically diagnosed when symptoms occur within 3 days to 1 month after the trauma.
  • • Option A) Acute Stress Disorder
  • • Option B) Generalized Anxiety Disorder - Characterized by chronic, excessive worry about various topics, not linked to a specific traumatic event.
  • • Option B) Generalized Anxiety Disorder
  • • Option C) Major Depressive Disorder - Primarily involves persistent depressive symptoms, without the reliving of trauma or avoidance behaviors.
  • • Option C) Major Depressive Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PTSD is characterized by intrusive memories, avoidance, negative changes in mood and cognition, and heightened arousal following a traumatic event, persisting for more than one month.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic concerned about premature ejaculation, which is causing distress in his relationship. He reports that this issue has been ongoing for several years and occurs within one minute of vaginal penetration. Which of the following psychological approaches is most appropriate for managing his condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The squeeze technique is a specific non-pharmacological approach often used to manage premature ejaculation . It involves the partner (or the individual himself) squeezing the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for about 30 seconds just before ejaculation. This can help delay ejaculation and over time can help extend the duration of sexual intercourse.
  • • squeeze technique
  • • Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 532.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): While CBT can be helpful in addressing underlying anxiety or stress that may contribute to sexual dysfunction, it is not a specific technique for managing premature ejaculation. CBT might be more appropriate if there were significant psychological factors contributing to the problem.
  • • Option A) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT):
  • • Option B) Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not applicable to the treatment of premature ejaculation.
  • • Option B) Exposure and Response Prevention:
  • • Option D) Sensate Focus Exercises: These exercises, developed by Masters and Johnson, are used to reduce performance anxiety and enhance sexual communication and intimacy, in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.
  • • Option D) Sensate Focus Exercises:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The squeeze technique is a specific non-pharmacological method used to manage premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis (coronal ridge of glans) before ejaculation to help delay it. Another technique used for premature ejaculation is stop-start technique (aka Seman’s technique). This technique involves sexual stimulation until the man recognizes that he is about to ejaculate. The stimulation is then removed for about 30 seconds and then resumed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic seeking help to quit smoking. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking and has attempted to quit several times in the past using nicotine gum and patches without success. He reports smoking about 1 pack per day and experiences strong cravings and irritability when he tries to quit. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacological management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Varenicline is a partial agonist at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, which helps reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. It has been shown to be more effective than both nicotine replacement therapy and bupropion for smoking cessation.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Bupropion: Bupropion is also used for smoking cessation but is generally less effective than varenicline. It works by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine.
  • • Option A. Bupropion:
  • • Option C. Nicotine nasal spray: This is a form of nicotine replacement therapy and can be helpful, but the patient has already tried similar therapies without success.
  • • Option C. Nicotine nasal spray:
  • • Option D. Nortriptyline: Nortriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that can be used off-label for smoking cessation but is not the first-line treatment and has more side effects compared to other options.
  • • Option D. Nortriptyline:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Varenicline is a highly effective first-line pharmacological option for smoking cessation, superior to both nicotine replacement therapy and bupropion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness for the past year. She reports falling asleep suddenly and without warning, even during activities like eating and talking. She also describes experiencing vivid hallucinations as she falls asleep or wakes up and episodes of sudden muscle weakness triggered by laughter. Her sleep at night is often disrupted. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is often associated with cataplexy.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be confirmed by a polysomnography followed by a multiple sleep latency test.

options.label: C
options.text: The symptoms can be effectively managed with regular use of caffeine and scheduled naps alone.

options.label: D
options.text: It is characterized by a deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) in the cerebrospinal fluid.

questions.correct_answer: C. The symptoms can be effectively managed with regular use of caffeine and scheduled naps alone.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The statement that the symptoms can be effectively managed with regular use of caffeine and scheduled naps alone is false. While scheduled naps and caffeine can help manage symptoms, pharmacological treatment is often necessary for effective management, including stimulants and medications for cataplexy.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Narcolepsy is often associated with cataplexy: This is true. Cataplexy is a hallmark feature of narcolepsy with cataplexy.
  • • Option A. Narcolepsy is often associated with cataplexy:
  • • Option B. Diagnosis of narcolepsy can be confirmed by a polysomnography followed by a multiple sleep latency test: This is true. These tests are essential for diagnosing narcolepsy by demonstrating the rapid onset of REM sleep.
  • • Option B. Diagnosis of narcolepsy can be confirmed by a polysomnography followed by a multiple sleep latency test:
  • • Option D. Narcolepsy is characterized by a deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) in the cerebrospinal fluid: This is true. A deficiency of hypocretin-1 (orexin-A) is a key feature of narcolepsy with cataplexy.
  • • Option D. Narcolepsy is characterized by a deficiency of hypocretin (orexin) in the cerebrospinal fluid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Narcolepsy is characterized by reduced latency of REM sleep. They present with hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations, cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone), sleep attacks (irresistible urge to sleep), and sleep paralysis. It is due to deficiency of hypocretin. Immune-mediated disorder, causes destruction of hypocretin-secreting neurons project from the hypothalamus. It is strong associated with human leucocyte antigen class II (HLA-DR2 and HLA-DQB1*0602). Effective management of narcolepsy typically requires a combination of behavioral strategies and pharmacological treatments to address excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 491.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his recent behavioral changes. She notes that over the past six months, he has become increasingly socially isolated, often responding to unseen stimuli, and expressing bizarre beliefs about being constantly watched by his neighbors. Physical examination reveals a heart murmur and hypocalcemic tetany. On further questioning, the mother recalls that during his childhood, he had recurrent infections and required cardiac surgery for a congenital heart defect. Genetic testing is being considered. Which genetic disease, associated with the patient's presentation, has a known increased risk of the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's congenital heart defect, recurrent infections, hypocalcemic tetany, and psychiatric symptoms are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome). DiGeorge syndrome has a heightened risk of psychiatric disorders, especially schizophrenia.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B) Klinefelter’s syndrome- presents with symptoms related to an extra X chromosome in males, leading to features like tall stature, testicular atrophy, and infertility.
  • • Option B) Klinefelter’s syndrome-
  • • Option C) Down’s syndrome- associated with intellectual disability, characteristic facial features, and a predisposition for congenital heart disease and early-onset Alzheimer's disease.
  • • Option C) Down’s syndrome-
  • • Option D) Neurofibromatosis- characterized by neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and Lisch nodules, with two major types: NF1 and NF2. NF1 can be associated with learning disabilities but not specifically schizophrenia.
  • • Option D) Neurofibromatosis-

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 361.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife, who reports a year-long history of the patient's declining memory and cognitive abilities. The patient was previously diagnosed with a type of cortical dementia. Which of the following is NOT classified as a cortical dementia?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lewy body dementia (LBD) is not classified as a purely cortical dementia. LBD involves both cortical and subcortical brain regions, which distinguishes it from typical cortical dementias. LBD is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies (abnormal protein deposits) in the brain and exhibits a mix of symptoms that include cognitive impairment, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian motor symptoms. The involvement of subcortical structures contributes to the motor and autonomic symptoms seen in LBD.
  • • Lewy body dementia
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A) Alzheimer's disease: This is the most common form of cortical dementia. Patients with Alzheimer's typically present with memory impairment, especially short-term memory.
  • • Option A) Alzheimer's disease:
  • • Option B) Frontotemporal dementia: Another form of cortical dementia. Symptoms may vary but often include personality and behavior changes or language disturbances.
  • • Option B) Frontotemporal dementia:
  • • Option D) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: A rare, rapidly progressive form of cortical dementia caused by prions. It leads to severe cognitive impairment, myoclonus, and neurological deficits.
  • • Option D) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lewy body dementia, while involving the cortex, is not purely cortical dementia as it affects both cortical and subcortical structures.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Erectile dysfunction primarily affects the arousal phase of the sexual cycle, where the inability to achieve or maintain an erection occurs. This phase involves the physiological process necessary for erection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Desire: Involves the initial sexual interest or libido, which is not primarily affected by erectile dysfunction.
  • • Option A. Desire:
  • • Option C. Orgasm: Involves the climax of sexual activity, and is not the phase where erectile dysfunction occurs.
  • • Option C. Orgasm:
  • • Option D. Resolution: Refers to the return of physiological functions to the baseline
  • • Option D. Resolution:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of the arousal phase of the normal sexual cycle.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 127.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man reports having recurrent impulses to speak negatively about deities when he sees temples or individuals in religious attire. Trying to suppress these urges makes him anxious, so he mentally recites a prayer to cope. Which condition best aligns with his presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is characterized by presence of obsessions (recurrent and intrusive thoughts, images or impulses which cause marked anxiety or distress) and compulsive acts (repetitive behaviors such as handwashing, checking or mental acts such as counting, praying that person performs in response to an obsession).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man seeks help due to feelings of sadness, concerns about his future, and sporadic episodes of crying when he's alone. However, he continues to find joy in watching films and playing cricket with friends. These symptoms emerged after ending a 2-year relationship. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presentation of a 26-year-old man experiencing feelings of sadness, concerns about the future, and episodes of crying, which began after the end of a significant relationship, is suggestive of Adjustment Disorder . Adjustment Disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor (in this case, the end of a relationship) occurring within three months of the onset of the stressor . These symptoms are significant but do not meet the criteria for Major Depressive Disorder, as the individual continues to enjoy some activities (watching films and playing cricket).
  • • Adjustment Disorder
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Major Depressive Disorder: While some symptoms overlap, the fact that the individual still finds joy in certain activities and the symptoms are clearly linked to a specific stressor makes Major Depressive Disorder less likely.
  • • Option A. Major Depressive Disorder:
  • • Option B. Acute Stress Disorder: This typically occurs within four weeks of a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as intrusive memories, negative mood, dissociation, avoidance, and arousal. The symptoms described here do not align with the typical presentation of Acute Stress Disorder.
  • • Option B. Acute Stress Disorder:
  • • Option D. Generalized Anxiety Disorder: This involves persistent and excessive worry about various aspects of life, not specifically linked to a recent stressor. The symptoms described are more consistent with Adjustment Disorder.
  • • Option D. Generalized Anxiety Disorder:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adjustment disorders are characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems, or death of a loved one. It presents with anxiety and depressive symptoms, but the symptoms are not severe enough to make the diagnosis of depression or an anxiety disorder.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 429-430.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man, who works as an auto driver, visits the clinic expressing deep anxiety about contracting HIV. Despite undergoing multiple HIV tests over the past six months at various clinics, all of which have come back negative, he remains intensely fearful. The mere thought of possibly having an HIV infection causes him significant distress. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypochondriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances. Management includes primarily psychotherapy (CBT), and pharmacotherapy for comorbid psychiatric disorders.
  • ➤ Preoccupation with illness- Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis)
  • ➤ Preoccupation with somatic symptoms- Somatic symptom disorder

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 453.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of muscle aches, runny nose, yawning, and dilated pupils for the past 48 hours. He mentions he stopped using heroin three days ago after using it daily for several years. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation with muscle aches, runny nose, yawning, and dilated pupils after discontinuing heroin use is consistent with opioid withdrawal symptoms . Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist that is used in the management of opioid withdrawal and maintenance therapy. It provides a stable level of opioids in the body, thus preventing the acute symptoms of withdrawal and helping to reduce cravings.
  • • Methadone
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Administration of diazepam. Diazepam is not the first-line treatment for opioid withdrawal. While benzodiazepines may be used in the management of alcohol withdrawal, they are not the primary treatment for opioid withdrawal.
  • • Option A. Administration of diazepam.
  • • Option C.Administration of naltrexone. Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used primarily in the prevention of relapse after detoxification. It is not used to treat the acute symptoms of opioid withdrawal as it can precipitate withdrawal if given to someone who has opioids in their system.
  • • Option C.Administration of naltrexone.
  • • Option D. Administration of naloxone. Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose, especially in cases of respiratory depression. It is not used in the routine management of opioid withdrawal as it would exacerbate withdrawal symptoms.
  • • Option D. Administration of naloxone.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Here, the primary focus lies in managing withdrawal symptoms. Medications typically employed include long-acting opioids such as methadone or buprenorphine. Due to their agonist action at opioid receptors, both medications effectively suppress withdrawal symptoms. Other opioids, like dextro-propoxyphene, may also be utilized. Detoxification medications are generally required for a period of 2-3 weeks. An alternative approach involves using clonidine for detoxification. However, clonidine offers considerably less symptom reduction compared to buprenorphine or methadone. As a result, clonidine is often used as an adjunct to methadone or buprenorphine during the detoxification process.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 295.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) after he stopped using cannabis five days ago, which he had been taking daily for the past two years. A diagnosis of cannabis withdrawal was made based on his presentation. Which of the following is a recognized symptom of cannabis withdrawal?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Insomnia is a recognized symptom of cannabis withdrawal. Cannabis withdrawal can occur in individuals who have been using the drug heavily and then significantly reduce or stop their use. Along with insomnia, other symptoms of cannabis withdrawal may include irritability, depressed mood, anxiety, decreased appetite, and cravings for cannabis.
  • • Insomnia
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Auditory hallucinations: While heavy and chronic use of cannabis might be associated with psychosis in predisposed individuals, auditory hallucinations are not a typical feature of cannabis withdrawal.
  • • Option A. Auditory hallucinations:
  • • Option B. Generalized tonic-clonic seizures: Seizures are not a recognized symptom of cannabis withdrawal. They are more commonly associated with withdrawal from substances like alcohol (complicated withdrawal) or benzodiazepines.
  • • Option B. Generalized tonic-clonic seizures:
  • • Option C. Increased appetite: Decreased appetite, rather than increased appetite, is more commonly associated with cannabis withdrawal.
  • • Option C. Increased appetite:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cannabis withdrawal syndrome may manifest with mild symptoms one to two weeks after stopping use. These symptoms include irritability and anxiety, reduced appetite, depressed mood, and difficulties with sleep, such as insomnia and strange dreams. Additionally, physical symptoms like abdominal pain, tremors, headaches, sweating, fever, or chills may occur.
  • ➤ irritability

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 288-289.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain, extreme agitation, and confusion. He has dilated pupils and is excessively sweating. His friends mention that he snorted a substance at a party. On examination, his heart rate is 128 bpm, his blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg, and he has repetitive, purposeless movements of his hands. Which of the following is the most likely substance responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation is consistent with acute cocaine intoxication . Cocaine , a powerful central nervous system stimulant, can cause symptoms such as chest pain (due to its cardiovascular effects), extreme agitation, confusion, dilated pupils, excessive sweating, tachycardia (elevated heart rate), hypertension (high blood pressure), and stereotypy (repetitive, purposeless movements). The fact that the patient snorted a substance at a party, a common route of administration for cocaine, further supports this diagnosis.
  • • Cocaine
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Methamphetamine: While methamphetamine can also cause similar stimulant effects, the acute presentation of chest pain and the specific context of snorting a substance at a party makes cocaine more likely.
  • • Option A. Methamphetamine:
  • • Option C. Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD): LSD is a hallucinogen and typically presents with perceptual changes, hallucinations, and altered mental state, but not with the severe cardiovascular effects and agitation typical of cocaine intoxication.
  • • Option C. Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD):
  • • Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP): PCP can cause agitation, delirium, and hallucinations, but it is also associated with nystagmus (rapid involuntary movement of the eyes), which is not mentioned in this scenario. Moreover, the cardiovascular effects seen in this patient are more characteristic of cocaine use.
  • • Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication is characterized by euphoria, pupillary dilatation, tachycardia, hypertension, and sweating. Acute intoxication with moderate to high doses of cocaine may be associated with paranoid ideations , auditory hallucinations, and visual illusions. The patients also occasionally report tactile hallucinations (feeling of insects crawling under the skin), also known as cocaine bugs . (also known as formication and magnan phenomenon ).
  • ➤ paranoid ideations
  • ➤ cocaine bugs
  • ➤ formication
  • ➤ magnan phenomenon

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 304.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the psychiatric outpatient clinic with his mother. She describes her son as a "loner" who has few friends and seems indifferent to social relationships. He has always preferred solitary activities and has little interest in intimacy or sexual relationships. She adds that he does not seem to derive pleasure from social interactions and often appears indifferent to praise or criticism. Given the described features, which of the following cluster A personality disorders is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The personality disorders are grouped into three clusters: A, B, and C. The features described in the vignette are consistent with a Cluster A personality disorder, specifically Schizoid Personality Disorder (SPD). Schizoid Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals with SPD often appear aloof, indifferent to praise or criticism, and have a limited desire for intimate or sexual relationships. They prefer solitary activities and do not derive pleasure from being part of a social group.
  • • Schizoid Personality Disorder (SPD). Schizoid Personality Disorder
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Paranoid Personality Disorder: This is characterized by a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others such that their motives are interpreted as malevolent. People with this disorder are often on the lookout for trickery and are very guarded in their interactions with others.
  • • Option A. Paranoid Personality Disorder:
  • • Option C. Schizotypal Personality Disorder: People with this disorder often have eccentric behavior and thoughts (like magical thinking). They might have odd beliefs or "magical thinking" but do not have true hallucinations or delusions as seen in schizophrenia.
  • • Option C. Schizotypal Personality Disorder:
  • • Option D. Avoidant Personality Disorder: This is a Cluster C personality disorder characterized by a pattern of social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation. People with this disorder desire social relationships but are deeply afraid of rejection, which is different from the indifference seen in SPD.
  • • Option D. Avoidant Personality Disorder:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Schizoid Personality Disorder, a Cluster A personality disorder, are detached from social relationships and prefer solitary activities . They are emotionally cold and indifferent to praise or criticism. They appear self-absorbed and lost in daydreams and may be preoccupied with fantasies.
  • ➤ detached
  • ➤ prefer solitary activities
  • ➤ emotionally cold

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 562-563.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic for counseling. She describes herself as a perfectionist and states that she gets overly upset when minor details of her plans do not go exactly as intended. She spends hours organizing her books, clothing, and office desk and gets frustrated when someone disrupts the order. She believes her ways are the "right" ways and often feels that others are not doing things correctly. She is also described by her peers as being overly conscientious and rigid about matters of ethics. Which of the following personality disorders best describes her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anankastic personality disorder , also known as obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD), is characterized by a chronic preoccupation with rules, orderliness, and control. People with this disorder can be perfectionists, and they are often high achievers, but their obsession with perfection can interfere with their productivity. They may insist that their way of doing things is the only right way and may be very critical of others. Unlike obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), individuals with OCPD do not have obsessions and compulsions; rather, their behavior is driven by their belief system.
  • • Anankastic personality disorder
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Histrionic personality disorder: Individuals with this disorder are characterized by a pattern of seeking attention and being excessively emotional.
  • • Option A. Histrionic personality disorder:
  • • Option B. Avoidant personality disorder: It is characterized by feelings of extreme social inhibition, inadequacy, and sensitivity to negative criticism and rejection.
  • • Option B. Avoidant personality disorder:
  • • Option D. Schizotypal personality disorder: People with this disorder often have odd beliefs, speech, and behavior, but they are also able to form bonds with others.
  • • Option D. Schizotypal personality disorder:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Anankastic personality disorder are preoccupied with rules and regulations. They give excessive importance to details and show perfectionism that interferes with task completion (since they want everything to be perfect, it often results in significant delays). They are inflexible and insist that others agree to their demands. They are excessively devoted to work and may not have any time for leisure ​​activities. They are formal and serious and often lack a sense of humor. The DSM-5 uses the diagnosis of "obsessive-compulsive personality disorder" for these patients. Management usually involves psychotherapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student presents to the clinic with concerns about her eating habits. She mentions that she often eats large quantities of food in a short time, during which she feels a lack of control. After these binge episodes, she reports feeling very guilty and compensates by inducing vomiting. On physical examination, you notice dental erosions and parotid gland swelling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient's clinical presentation of recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors, such as vomiting, points towards a diagnosis of: C) Bulimia nervosa. This disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of consuming large amounts of food in a short time (binge eating) accompanied by a lack of control and followed by compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain (e.g., vomiting, excessive exercise, fasting). Physical findings can include dental erosions (from frequent vomiting) and parotid gland swelling.
  • • C) Bulimia nervosa.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating/purging type: This disorder shares the binge-eating and purging behaviors with bulimia nervosa, but patients with this type of anorexia nervosa are significantly underweight and have a distorted body image.

Binge eating disorder: Patients with this disorder have binge-eating episodes similar to those in bulimia nervosa, but they do not use inappropriate compensatory behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise. questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his family. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia five years ago. Despite trying and adhering to three different antipsychotic medications (risperidone, haloperidol and olanzapine) for an adequate duration and at therapeutic doses, he continues to have auditory hallucinations and delusions that others are trying to harm him. He remains socially isolated and rarely leaves his home. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Add a second-generation antipsychotic to the existing treatment.

questions.correct_answer: A. Start a trial of clozapine.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is experiencing treatment-resistant schizophrenia, which is defined as failure to achieve symptom remission despite trials with two or more antipsychotic medications at adequate doses and durations. Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is particularly effective for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. It is the only antipsychotic demonstrated to be effective where others have failed. However, it's reserved for treatment-resistant cases due to potential adverse effects like agranulocytosis, and thus, requires regular blood monitoring.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Add a second-generation antipsychotic to the existing treatment: While combination antipsychotic therapy is sometimes tried in clinical practice, evidence for its efficacy is limited, and it can increase the risk of side effects.
  • • Option B. Add a second-generation antipsychotic to the existing treatment:
  • • Option C. Refer for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT): ECT can be effective in some patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia, but it's typically considered after trials of multiple medications, including clozapine.
  • • Option C. Refer for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT):
  • • Option D. Increase the dose of olanzapine: Simply increasing the dose of olanzapine beyond therapeutic levels is not indicated and could increase the risk of side effects.
  • • Option D. Increase the dose of olanzapine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment-resistant Schizophrenia (TRS) is defined as a lack of response to two different antipsychotics given at adequate dosages for adequate duration of 4 to 6 weeks. Clozapine is the treatment of choice for TRS .
  • ➤ Clozapine
  • ➤ treatment of choice for TRS

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 190.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has had 6 months of involuntary movements and vocalizations, including excessive blinking, shoulder shrugging, and grunting. These behaviors are impacting his schoolwork and attention. What is the best pharmacological option for him?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms described in the 12-year-old boy, including involuntary movements and vocalizations (excessive blinking, shoulder shrugging, grunting), suggest a tic disorder , possibly Tourette syndrome. Clonidine , an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, is often used as a first-line treatment for tics due to its relatively mild side effect profile compared to other antipsychotic medications. Clonidine can help reduce the severity and frequency of tics and is generally well-tolerated, especially in children.
  • • Clonidine
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Pimozide: Pimozide is effective for tics, but it is not usually the first choice due to potential side effects, including the risk of cardiac side effects.

  • • Option C. Haloperidol:

  • • Option D. Risperidone:
  • • Given the child's age and the need to minimize potential side effects, clonidine is often considered a preferable initial treatment option for managing tic disorders in pediatric patients.

  • ➤ Clonidine and guanfacine are commonly used first-line options for managing tic disorders in children, especially when minimizing side effects is a priority. It is effective in reducing the severity and frequency of tics and generally has a lower risk of significant side effects compared to antipsychotic medications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of uncomfortable sensations in her legs, described as a crawling feeling, particularly at night. These sensations compel her to move her legs, providing temporary relief. Her symptoms have led to significant sleep disturbances. What is the most appropriate initial management for her condition?

questions.text: According to the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, an individual is empowered to make decisions regarding their preferred caregiver and treatment plan for potential future mental health episodes. What term is used to describe this legal provision?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the Mental Health Care Act 2017, the term used to describe the legal provision that allows an individual to make decisions regarding their preferred caregiver and treatment plan for potential future mental health episodes is " Advance Directive ." An Advance Directive is a legal document in which a person specifies what actions should be taken for their health if they are no longer able to make decisions for themselves due to incapacity. The Advance Directive is aimed at empowering individuals with mental illness to have a say in their treatment and ensuring that their preferences are respected.
  • • Advance Directive

  • • Other options:

Only 2 is correct: This option is incorrect because it ignores the contributions of M1, alpha-adrenergic, and 5HT2C receptors. 1 and 2 are correct: This option is incorrect because it excludes alpha-adrenergic and 5HT2C receptors, both implicated in the side effects.

  • • Option B) Korsakoff syndrome: Involves memory impairment and confabulation, typically following untreated Wernicke encephalopathy, and does not present acutely with the triad of symptoms described.
  • • Option B) Korsakoff syndrome:
  • • Option C) Alcohol intoxication: Usually presents with slurred speech, motor impairment, and altered mental status, but does not typically include the triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.
  • • Option C) Alcohol intoxication:
  • • Option D) Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium: Presents with agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity, but does not typically include the triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.
  • • Option D) Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke encephalopathy presents with the triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, and is commonly associated with chronic alcohol use and thiamine deficiency.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about his aggressive and defiant behavior over the past year. He has been involved in multiple physical fights at school, has stolen items from stores, and frequently lies to his parents and teachers. He also deliberately destroys property and shows no remorse for his actions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Conduct disorder is characterized by a pattern of behavior that violates the rights of others and societal norms, including aggression, destruction of property, deceitfulness, and theft, which fits this patient's presentation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Oppositional Defiant Disorder - Involves defiant and hostile behavior but does not include the severe violations of rights seen in conduct disorder.
  • • Option A. Oppositional Defiant Disorder -
  • • Option B. Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder - Characterized by inattention and hyperactivity, not the aggressive and antisocial behaviors described here.
  • • Option B. Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder -
  • • Option D. Intermittent Explosive Disorder - Involves sudden episodes of aggressive behavior, but does not account for the persistent pattern of antisocial behavior seen in conduct disorder.
  • • Option D. Intermittent Explosive Disorder -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conduct disorder is characterised by a persistent pattern of ‘disregard for rights of others’ and aggressive and dissocial behaviour, and manifests with the following-
  • ➤ Stealing , repeated lying, aggression, bullying, cruelty towards animals, disobedience, running away from school High risk of later development of antisocial personality disorder
  • ➤ Stealing , repeated lying, aggression, bullying, cruelty towards animals, disobedience, running away from school
  • ➤ High risk of later development of antisocial personality disorder

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 189.

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of atypical depression?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Early morning awakening is characteristic of melancholic depression, not atypical depression. Atypical depression features mood reactivity and at least two of the following: hypersomnia, significant weight gain or increased appetite, leaden paralysis, and a long-standing pattern of sensitivity to rejection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypersomnia: Excessive sleeping is a common symptom of atypical depression.
  • • Option A. Hypersomnia:
  • • Option B. Weight gain: Increased appetite and weight gain are often seen in atypical depression.
  • • Option B. Weight gain:
  • • Option C. Leaden paralysis: A feeling of heaviness in the limbs is typical of atypical depression.
  • • Option C. Leaden paralysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early morning awakening is a symptom of melancholic depression, whereas atypical depression includes hypersomnia, weight gain, and leaden paralysis.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380-382.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with flu-like symptoms, insomnia, nausea, and dizziness. She recently stopped taking her antidepressant medication abruptly, which she had been on for the past year for major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for the condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Paroxetine is known for causing significant discontinuation symptoms due to its short half-life. Abrupt cessation can lead to flu-like symptoms, insomnia, nausea, and dizziness, commonly referred to as antidepressant discontinuation syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fluoxetine: Has a long half-life, leading to fewer discontinuation symptoms when stopped abruptly.
  • • Option B. Fluoxetine:
  • • Option C. Sertraline: While it can cause discontinuation symptoms, they are generally less severe compared to Paroxetine due to its intermediate half-life.
  • • Option C. Sertraline:
  • • Option D. Escitalopram: Also has a relatively intermediate half-life, and discontinuation symptoms are typically less pronounced than with Paroxetine.
  • • Option D. Escitalopram:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paroxetine is associated with significant discontinuation symptoms due to its short half-life, making it the most likely cause of flu-like symptoms, insomnia, nausea, and dizziness when stopped abruptly.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 343-346.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency department with confusion, tremors, and increased thirst. He is currently on lithium for mood stabilization. He was recently started on a medication for his hypertension. Laboratory results reveal raised serum lithium levels. Which of the following antihypertensive medications is the most likely cause of his current symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ACE inhibitors can decrease renal clearance of lithium, leading to increased serum lithium levels and toxicity. Symptoms of lithium toxicity include confusion, tremors, and increased thirst, as observed in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Loop diuretics: Generally do not significantly affect lithium levels.
  • • Option B. Loop diuretics:
  • • Option C. Potassium-sparing diuretics: Can increase lithium levels but are less commonly associated with severe lithium toxicity compared to ACE inhibitors.
  • • Option C. Potassium-sparing diuretics:
  • • Option D. NSAIDs: While they can also increase lithium levels, they are not antihypertensive medications.
  • • Option D. NSAIDs:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drugs which increase the levels of Lithium include:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors Thiazide diuretics NSAIDs
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics
  • ➤ NSAIDs

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 254.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with bipolar disorder comes to her obstetrician for a routine prenatal visit. She is currently in her first trimester and has been taking a mood stabilizer. The obstetrician discusses the potential teratogenic effects of her medication. Which of the following mood stabilizers is most associated with teratogenic effects?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Valproate is highly teratogenic and is associated with a significantly increased risk of neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, when taken during pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Lamotrigine - Has a lower teratogenic risk compared to valproate but may still pose some risk, mainly oral clefts.
  • • Option A) Lamotrigine
  • • Option B) Lithium - Associated with an increased risk of cardiac defects, specifically Ebstein's anomaly, but not neural tube defects.
  • • Option B) Lithium
  • • Option D) Carbamazepine - Also associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects, but the risk is lower than that of valproate.
  • • Option D) Carbamazepine -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 692.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with an intense fear of dogs, which has been present since childhood. She avoids parks and public places where dogs might be present, and this avoidance significantly interferes with her daily activities and social life. She experiences palpitations, sweating, and a sense of impending doom when she encounters a dog. What is the most appropriate initial management for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Systematic desensitization is a form of behavioral therapy that gradually exposes the patient to the feared object or situation in a controlled manner, reducing the anxiety associated with the phobia over time.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) - Effective for many anxiety disorders, but systematic desensitization specifically targets phobias through gradual exposure.
  • • Option A. Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
  • • Option C. Psychoanalytic Therapy - Focuses on exploring unconscious conflicts and is not the first-line treatment for specific phobias.
  • • Option C. Psychoanalytic Therapy
  • • Option D. Supportive Counseling - Provides emotional support but does not directly address the phobia through exposure techniques.
  • • Option D. Supportive Counseling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ First line treatment of specific phobia is the psychotherapy which includes systematic desensitization, therapeutic graded exposure etc. Pharmacotherapy is at best used as an adjunct to psychotherapy. Among the pharmacological agents, SSRIs are considered to be the drug of choice .
  • ➤ SSRIs
  • ➤ drug of choice

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 9-month history of excessive worry about various aspects of her life, including her job, finances, and health. She reports feeling restless, easily fatigued, and has difficulty concentrating. She also experiences muscle tension and trouble sleeping. These symptoms have significantly impacted her daily functioning and relationships. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive worry about multiple aspects of life, lasting for six months or more, accompanied by symptoms such as restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, muscle tension, and sleep disturbances.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Major Depressive Disorder - Primarily involves persistent depressive symptoms, not chronic excessive worry.
  • • Option A. Major Depressive Disorder
  • • Option B. Panic Disorder - Characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, not the pervasive worry seen in GAD.
  • • Option B. Panic Disorder
  • • Option D. Social Anxiety Disorder - Involves intense fear of social or performance situations, not the generalized worry about various aspects of life.
  • • Option D. Social Anxiety Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized Anxiety Disorder involves chronic, excessive worry about multiple areas of life, lasting for six months or more, and includes symptoms such as restlessness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 405.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic two months after the sudden death of his wife in a car accident. He reports feeling overwhelmed and frequently finds himself thinking, "This can't be happening." He sometimes feels numb and detached from reality. He has trouble sleeping and has withdrawn from social activities. Which stage of grief is he most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Denial

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Denial is the first stage of grief, characterized by difficulty accepting reality, numbness, and detachment.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 847-848.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 1-year history of multiple physical symptoms, including headaches, abdominal pain, and fatigue. She frequently visits different doctors seeking answers and feels distressed and anxious about her health. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Somatic Symptom Disorder is characterized by multiple, persistent physical symptoms that cause significant distress and impairment, with no identifiable medical cause, as seen in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder - Involves excessive worry about various aspects of life, not primarily physical symptoms without a medical cause.
  • • Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder -
  • • Option C. Major Depressive Disorder - Primarily involves persistent depressive symptoms, not multiple unexplained physical complaints.
  • • Option C. Major Depressive Disorder -
  • • Option D. Illness Anxiety Disorder - Characterized by excessive worry about having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms, differing from the multiple distressing symptoms in Somatic Symptom Disorder.
  • • Option D. Illness Anxiety Disorder -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Somatic Symptom Disorder involves multiple, distressing physical symptoms without an identifiable medical cause, significantly impacting daily life.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 452.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic for a follow-up visit. During the conversation, when asked about his sleep patterns, he describes his entire evening routine in great detail before mentioning that he has difficulty falling asleep. Which of the following best describes this patient's thought process?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Circumstantiality is characterized by overly detailed and indirect speech that eventually reaches the point, as seen in this patient who provides excessive detail before answering questions directly.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tangentiality - The patient goes off on tangents and never returns to the original point, unlike in circumstantiality.
  • • Option A. Tangentiality -
  • • Option C. Flight of ideas - Rapidly shifting from one topic to another, typically seen in mania, and different from the detailed but eventually goal-directed speech in circumstantiality.
  • • Option C. Flight of ideas -
  • • Option D. Perseveration - Involves repeating the same response to different questions, which is not observed in this patient.
  • • Option D. Perseveration -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Circumstantiality involves overly detailed and indirect speech that eventually gets to the point, often seen in various psychiatric conditions.

References:

  • ↳ References- Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page 45.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic with concerns about her constant intrusive thoughts. She describes persistent, unwanted thoughts about contamination that cause significant anxiety. The above symptoms are classified as which of the following disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Possession

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessions are classified as disorders of possession of thought, characterized by intrusive and uncontrollable thoughts.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page 46.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of believing that his coworkers are conspiring against him to get him fired. He insists that they are spreading false rumors about him, despite no evidence to support his claims. He functions well in other areas of his life. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Delusional Disorder is characterized by the presence of one or more delusions for at least one month, without other significant impairments in functioning or the presence of hallucinations, mood disorders, or thought disorganization, as seen in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Paranoid Personality Disorder - Involves a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others, but not fixed delusions with clear conviction as seen in Delusional Disorder.
  • • Option A. Paranoid Personality Disorder -
  • • Option B. Schizophrenia - Involves a broader range of symptoms including hallucinations, disorganized speech, and significant functional impairment, not present here.
  • • Option B. Schizophrenia -
  • • Option D. Bipolar Disorder - Characterized by mood episodes, such as mania or depression, which are not observed in this patient.
  • • Option D. Bipolar Disorder -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delusional Disorder involves one or more persistent delusions without other significant psychiatric symptoms or functional impairments.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 345.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family due to unresponsiveness and immobility for the past two days. She has a history of major depressive disorder. On examination, she is mute, maintains a rigid posture, and resists any attempts to be moved. She also exhibits echolalia and echopraxia. Her vital signs and basic laboratory tests are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Benzodiazepines, particularly lorazepam, are considered the first-line treatment for catatonia due to their effectiveness in rapidly alleviating symptoms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Antipsychotic medications - Can potentially worsen catatonia and are not recommended as the initial treatment.
  • • Option A. Antipsychotic medications -
  • • Option B. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) - Effective for catatonia but usually reserved for cases refractory to benzodiazepines.
  • • Option B. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) -
  • • Option D. Antidepressant medications - Useful for underlying depression but not the first-line treatment for acute catatonic symptoms.
  • • Option D. Antidepressant medications -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment for catatonia, providing rapid relief of symptoms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe neck stiffness and involuntary upward eye movements that started a few hours ago. He was recently started on haloperidol for acute psychosis. On examination, he is in obvious distress with marked muscle spasms in his neck and eyes. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, is effective in treating acute dystonia by counteracting the effects of dopamine blockade caused by antipsychotics.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Haloperidol dose reduction - Reducing the dose may prevent future episodes but does not provide immediate relief of acute dystonia.
  • • Option A. Haloperidol dose reduction -
  • • Option B. Benzodiazepines - Can be used as an adjunct but are not the first-line treatment for acute dystonia.
  • • Option B. Benzodiazepines -
  • • Option D. Lithium - Used for mood stabilization and is not effective for treating acute dystonia.
  • • Option D. Lithium -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphenhydramine or other anticholinergic agents are the first-line treatments for acute dystonia induced by antipsychotic medications.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111
